Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

The questions in the Problem’s Introduction are examples of probability situations to help students consider the likelihood of particular events. Teaching Aid 1.1C: Probability of Events Happening can be used to launch the Unit. It contains links to predictions of 4 events.

Presenting the Challenge

Introduce Problem 1.1 by telling Kaleb’s story about how his mother wants to limit the time he spends on his electronic devices. He has decided to toss a cup to decide the amount of screen time he can have that day. His mother has decided he should toss a coin to decide the amount of screen time he can have that day. Before they conduct the experiments, have students predict, before they conduct the experiments, if they think Kaleb will get to have two hours of screen time. Before students conduct the experiments, have them predict if they think Kaleb will get to have two hours of screen time. Explain to students that they are going to conduct an experiment in order to test their predictions.

Discuss the need for students to make sure that the way they conduct the experiment will not affect, or bias, the outcome.

Suggested questions

  • What kinds of things could happen to affect the data you gather in this Problem? (You could toss the coin without spinning it or you could write down the wrong results.)
  • How should you toss a coin/cup to be sure you have a fair trial? (Perhaps the class can decide on a coin/cup-tossing technique that helps ensure the results are random.)
  • Suppose you always start with tails facing up when tossing a coin. Do you think this introduces bias? (Yes, the coin always starting tails up may affect the way it lands (heads up or tails up).)

Talk to the class about systematic bias, the introduction of bias through nonrandom ways of generating the data, such as always starting with tails facing up when tossing a coin. Discuss how systematic bias can affect what is learned from an experiment. (Language)

Let students know that collecting data in a random way can help to better predict what to expect when a coin/cup is tossed. In this case, random means that the coin’s/cup’s behavior is not affected in a predictable way by how it is tossed. That means there is no systematic bias in the data.

Distribute Learning Aid 1.1A: Coin-Toss Results and Learning Aid 1.1B: Cup-Toss Results to each group of two-three students. Explain that students are to toss a coin once for each day and record the result, (H or T), in the Result of Toss column. Toss the cup once for each day and record the result, (side or end) in the Result of Toss column. Make sure that students understand how to record their data.

  • What do you think will be the results of Kaleb’s experiment of flipping the coin 30 times? (Answers will vary. Record the class predictions to compare it with the experimental data during the Summary.)
  • What do you think will be the results of tossing the cup 30 times? (Answers will vary. Record the class predictions to compare it with the experimental data during the summary.)
